messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs (Spitzer, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-06-29T17:45:06Z
## Message ID: 20170629-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-06-28T15:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~360 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 26 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -80/-2 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2017-06-28T15:24:00-CME-001

2: S-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-06-28T16:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~400 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 39 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 17/37 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2017-06-28T16:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the 2017-06-28T15:24Z CME may affect Spitzer (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2017-07-02T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 
  
The simulation also indicates that the 2017-06-28T16:24Z CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2017-07-02T19:30Z (plus minus 7 hours).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CMEs: 2017-06-28T15:24:00-CME-001, 2017-06-28T16:24:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170629_010400_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170629_010400_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170629_010400_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170629_010400_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170629_010400_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170629_010400_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170629_010400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 21, 2017 - June 27, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-06-29T00:42:26Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-06-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-06-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170629-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period, with no significant CMEs or flares.    

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period, reaching a maximum of 104,000 pfu at 2017-06-21T19:00Z. This is a continuation of the Earth's outer radiation belt electron flux enhancement starting at 2017-06-17T19:25Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 on 2017-06-16.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate beginning of this week due to the enhancement on the energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-06-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-07-04T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate the next reporting period. There are some active regions currently on the solar disk capable of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  An active region that is just rotating to the east limb is already having some activity producing a coronal mass ejection on 2017-06-28.  Analysis of this CME is currently ongoing.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 14, 2017 - June 20, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-06-22T02:01:10Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-06-14T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-06-20T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170622-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-06-16T12:00Z-15:00Z and 2017-06-16T21:00Z-24:00Z.  This minor enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 on 2017-06-16.  The solar wind speed reached values of >600 km/s at the end of 2017-06-16.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-06-17T19:25Z and remained elevated crossing the threshold again on 2017-06-19T15:20Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20170617-AL-001, 20170617-AL-002, and 20170619-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the enhancement on the energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-06-20T06:48Z     ~530            C               -84/16                33                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-06-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-06-27T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate. There are several active regions present on the solar disk that could produce some flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream (currently located north-center disk) in the next couple days.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement Update
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-06-21T18:15:51Z
## Message ID: 20170621-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:
This is an update to the notifications with Activity ID: 2017-06-17T19:25:00-RBE-001 (see notifications 20170617-AL-001, 20170617-AL-002, and 20170619-AL-001). 

Continued significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first crossed 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-06-17T19:25Z and continues to be above the threshold.  

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-06-16T04:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-06-17T19:25:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 07, 2017 - June 13, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-06-15T01:45:49Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-06-07T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-06-13T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170615-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The index Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-06-11T15:00Z-2017-06-11T18:00Z.  This enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated to a combination of the arrival of a slow (S-type) CME that started on 2017-06-07T21:36Z that produced an interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-06-11T13:22Z, and a weak coronal hole high speed stream (500-550km/s).  Solar wind speed reached values of >550 km/s on 2017-06-12.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-06-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-06-20T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming reporting period as there are no large active regions visible on the solar disk. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be somewhat elevated for the upcoming period due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream in a few days (with 3 low latitude coronal holes close to disk center on 2017-06-14) which can cause a moderate geomagnetic disturbance with a enhancement of the energetic electron flux at the Earth's outer radiation belt.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 31, 2017 - June 06, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-06-07T23:58:29Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-05-31T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-06-06T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170607-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-06-03T15:00Z-18:00Z.  There was an arrival detected by DSCOVR at L1 of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-06-03T06:00Z.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s at the end of the day of 2017-06-03.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a couple of coronal holes high speed streams on 2017-06-02T06:00Z and 2017-06-05T08:30Z, respectively.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2017-06-03.  It seems that this event may have been combined with a CME (<500 km/s) that started on 2017-05-29T08:48Z. The solar wind speed reached values of >600 km/s for the second coronal hole high speed stream on 2017-06-06.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

2017-06-03T11:24Z     ~627            C                55/8                 10                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-06-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-06-13T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are several active regions on the front and the far side of the Sun (e.g. AR 12661) that are capable of producing flares and coronal mass ejections.  There is currently an Earth-facing side eruption seen from the SDO AIA imagery that started around 2017-06-07T16:40Z following a B4.4 class flare from the active region 12661. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due the possible impact of this eruption, but more analysis and images are needed to see if a coronal mass ejection was produced and evaluate its possible impact.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 24, 2017 - May 30, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-06-01T01:48:20Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-05-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-05-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170601-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. No CMEs with a speed above 500 km/s where detected in the available coronagraph imagery.  

Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=7 for the reporting period. This strong increase in geomagnetic activity was due to the CME arrival detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-05-27T14:47Z (see notification 20170527-AL-001). The CME was first observed on the coronagraph imagery around 2017-05-23T05:00Z (see notification 20170523-AL-002). Kp first reached values of 6 during the synoptic periods of 2017-05-27T21:00Z to 2017-05-28T03:00Z and 2017-05-28T06:00Z to 2017-05-28T09:00Z. The peak for geomagnetic activity with Kp=7 occurred in the synoptic period 2017-05-28T03:00Z to 2017-05-28T06:00Z (see notifications 20170528-AL-001, 20170528-AL-002, 20170528-AL-003).

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES continued to be above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu. This increase started at 2017-05-21T12:25Z and the threshold was crossed several times since then up to the arrival of the CME mentioned above (see notifications 20170521-AL-001, 20170521-AL-002, 20170523-AL-001, 20170525-AL-001). The elevated energetic electron flux levels are associated with a coronal hole high speed stream starting at 2017-05-19T18:08Z.  Solar wind speed reached values of >700 km/s on 2017-05-20.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt and the CME arrival described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)

None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

None Observed  

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. There are 2 active regions currently visible on the Earth's facing side and two more are expected to rotate on, and all of them show low to moderate activity with some chance of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  A minor coronal hole high speed stream is expected later in the coming week due to a small equatorial coronal hole observed close to disk center on 2017-05-30.
